## My first function

```{r}
x_vec = rnorm(25, mean = 5, sd = 3)

(x_vec - mean(x_vec)) / sd(x_vec)
```

I want a function to compute z-scores
```{r}
z_scores = function(x) {    
  
  if (!is.numeric(x)) {
  stop("Argument x should be numeric")
  } 
  
  else if (length(x) == 1) {
  stop("Z scores cannot be computed for length 1 vectors")
  }
  z = (x - mean(x)) / sd(x)
  z
  
}  #function writing

z_scores(x_vec) 
```

Try my function on some other things. These should give errors.
```{r, error = TRUE}
z_scores(3)

z_scores("my name is jeff")

z_scores(iris)

z_scores(c(TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, TRUE))

z_scores(sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), 25, replace = TRUE))
```

## Multiple outputs

```{r}
mean_and_sd = function(x) {    
  
  if (!is.numeric(x)) {
  stop("Argument x should be numeric")
  } 
  
  else if (length(x) == 1) {
  stop("Z scores cannot be computed for length 1 vectors")
  }
  
  mean_x = mean(x)
  sd_x = sd(x)
  
  tibble(
    mean = mean_x, 
    sd = sd_x
  )
}
```

Check that the function works
```{r}
x_vec = rnorm(1000, mean = 3, sd = 4) #created a vector

mean_and_sd(x_vec)
```

## Multiple inputs

I'd like to do this in a function
```{r}
sim_data = tibble(                   #created a dataframe
  x = rnorm(30, mean = 2, sd = 3)
)

sim_data |> 
  summarize(
    mu_hat = mean(x),
    sigma_hat = sd(x)
  )
```

```{r}
sim_mean_sd = function(n, mu = 2, sigma = 3) {
  
  sim_data = tibble(
    x = rnorm(n=n, mean = mu, sd = sigma),
  )
  
  sim_data |> 
    summarize(
      mu_hat = mean(x),
      sigma_hat = sd(x)
    )
}

sim_mean_sd(100, 6, 3) #each time you run, you get slightly different number, showing variability of sample if you run it over and over again

sim_mean_sd(n = 100) #used default (first line)
```

## Functions as arguments
```{r}
my_summary = function(x, summ_func){
  
  summ_func(x)
  
}

x_vec = rnorm(100, 3, 7)

mean(x_vec)
median (x_vec)

my_summary(x_vec, mean)
my_summary(x_vec, IQR)
my_summary(x_vec, sd)
```
